[[Otto Kuntze|Kuntze]] (1891) }} {{mycomorphbox | name = ''Lactarius subdulcis'' | whichGills = adnate | capShape = convex | hymeniumType=gills | stipeCharacter=bare | ecologicalType=mycorrhizal | sporePrintColor=cream | howEdible=edible }} {{stack end}} '''''Lactarius subdulcis''''', commonly known as the '''mild milkcap''' or '''beech milk cap''', is an [[edible mushroom]] in the genus ''[[Lactarius]]''. It is brown in colour, with a large number of gills and a particularly thin layer of flesh in the cap. [[Mycorrhizal]], the mushroom is found from late summer to late autumn at the base of [[beech|beech trees]] in small groups or individually, where it is one of the two most common species of fungi. Alternatively, it can be found in large groups in fields, sometimes with more than a hundred individual mushrooms. It is found in Europe, and, despite previous research to the contrary, is absent in North America. Although considered edible, it is not particularly useful as food due to its [[ivy]]-like taste and the fact that more choice mushrooms will be easily found at the same time. ''L. subdulcis'' is known for its abundant, sweet-tasting milk that, unlike the latex of some of its relatives, does not stain fabric yellow. == Taxonomy == ''Lactarius subdulcis'' was first described as ''Agaricus subdulcis'' by mycologist [[Christian Hendrik Persoon]] in 1801,{{cite book |title= Synopsis methodica fungorum|last= Persoon|first= Christian Hendrick|authorlink= Christian Hendrik Persoon|year= 1801}} before English mycologist [[Samuel Frederick Gray]] placed it in its current genus ''[[Lactarius]]'' in 1821 in his ''The Natural Arrangement of British Plants''.{{cite book | last=Gray | first=S. F. |authorlink= Samuel Frederick Gray| title=The Natural Arrangement of British Plants | publisher=|location=London | year=1821| page= 625}} The specific epithet is derived from [[Latin]] words ''sub'' "under", and ''dulcis'' "sweet", after the milk's delayed sweet taste.{{cite book | last = Haas |first=Hans | year = 1969 | title = The Young Specialist looks at Fungi |page= 221| publisher = Burke | isbn= 0-222-79409-7}} As well as mild milk cap, beech milk cap is an alternate common name.{{cite book |title=The Great Encyclopedia of Mushrooms |last=Lamaison |first=Jean-Louis |author2=Polese, Jean-Marie |year=2005 |publisher=Könemann |isbn=3-8331-1239-5|page= 50}} == Description == [[File:Lactarius subdulcis - Lindsey 1b.jpg|thumb|left|''L. subdulcis'' is known for the large amounts of milk it produces.]] ''Lactarius subdulcis'' has a convex [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] of {{convert|3|–|7|cm|in|round=0.5|abbr=on}} across that later develops a depression.{{cite book|title= Mushrooms and Other Fungi of Great Britain and Europe|last= Phillips|first= Roger|year= 1981|publisher= [[Pan Books]]|location= London|isbn= 0-330-26441-9|pages=88–89}} It sometimes has a small [[umbo (mycology)|umbo]], and in colour can be a reddish-brown, rusty or dark-cinnamon, later paling to [[buff (color)|buff]], though darker in the middle. The cap can be fairly rigid to flexible, and smooth to slightly wrinkled. At first, the margin is incurved though it is sometimes slightly furrowed. The [[stipe (mycology)|stem]] is 3–7 cm long and between 6 and 13 mm thick, and is generally cylindrical though can be club-shaped. The stem is sometimes furrowed lengthwise, and is generally the same colour as the cap, though paler at the top. The [[trama (mycology)|flesh]] is pale and there is only a thin layer in the cap. The crowded [[lamella (mycology)|gills]] are [[adnation|adnate]] to slightly [[decurrent]], and can be white or pink in colour. It has white, plentiful milk that does not stain fabrics yellow, differentiating it from other species of ''[[Lactarius]]'', such as ''[[L. decipiens]]''. It has a faint, oily scent.{{cite book |title= The Encyclopedia of Fungi of Britain and Europe|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=ULhwByKCyEwC&pg=PA308&dq=%22Lactarius+subdulcis%22|accessdate= 2008-08-08|last= Jordan|first= Michael|year= 2004|publisher= [[Frances Lincoln]]|isbn= 978-0-7112-2378-3|page= 308}} === Spores === ''Lactarius subdulcis'' has cream [[spore print]] with a slight salmon tinge. The spores are oval, with largish warts of around 1 [[micrometre]] (μm) which are joined by a well-developed network of mostly thin ridges. The spores measure 7.5–11 μm by 6.5–9 μm, and are [[amyloid]] or [[ellipsoid]] in shape. == Distribution and habitat == ''Lactarius subdulcis'' is found in Europe; it does not occur in North America, although a number of similar brownish-orange species were formerly classified under this species.{{cite book |author=David Arora |year=1986 |title=Mushrooms Demystified |publisher=Ten Speed Press |isbn=0-89815-169-4 |page=82 |url-access=registration |url=https://archive.org/details/mushroomsdemysti00aror_0 }} It is found in broad-leaved woodland, especially on the floor at the base of [[beech]] trees. Along with ''[[Lactarius vellereus|L. vellereus]]'', ''L. subdulcis'' is the most common fungi found on beech trees.{{cite book |title= Plant Surface Microbiology|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=rbhhkolNX2kC&pg=PA200&dq=%22Lactarius+subdulcis%22 |accessdate= 2008-08-08|last= Varma|first= Ajit|year= 2004|publisher= [[Springer (publisher)|Springer]]|location= Germany|isbn= 978-3-540-00923-8|pages= 200}} The mushrooms can be found from late summer to late autumn, and are common. They are found individually, or in small groups. They can also be found in fields, generally appearing in large batches, with groups of over a hundred mushrooms not uncommon.{{cite book |title= Edible Mushrooms|last= Christensen|first= Clyde Martin|year= 1981|publisher= [[University of Minnesota Press]]|isbn= 978-0-8166-1049-5|page= 47|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=87MEgHtb9KUC&pg=PA47&lpg=PA47&dq=%22lactarius+subdulcis%22}} == Edibility == ''Lactarius subdulcis'' has a mild taste with a slightly bitter after-taste. Though considered [[edible mushroom|edible]] after cooking, it is not recommended, as it has a taste reminiscent of [[ivy]].{{cite book |title= Mushrooms and Toadstools|last= Pegler|first= David N.|year= 1983|publisher= Mitchell Beazley Publishing|location= London|isbn= 0-85533-500-9|pages= 78}} There are a number of other mushrooms that appear at the same time and in the same areas as ''L. subdulcis'' that are preferable to it, including ''[[Lactarius mitissimus|L. mitissimus]]'', meaning that ''L. subdulcis'' is not particularly useful as a foodstuff.{{cite book |title= British Edible Fungi|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=lOrahbcWdKAC&pg=PA236&dq=%22Lactarius+subdulcis%22|accessdate= 2008-08-08|last= Cooke|first= M.C.|year= 2007|publisher= Read Books|isbn= 978-1-4067-5608-1|pages= 85–86}} The milk is one of distinguishing features, having a sweet taste that turns bitter in the mouth, with ''L. subdulcis'' being considered a sweet milk mushroom. == See also == {{Portal|Fungi}} * [[List of Lactarius species|List of ''Lactarius'' species]] == References == {{Reflist|2}} == External links == {{Commons}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081120092212/http://www.rogersmushrooms.com/gallery/DisplayBlock~bid~6346~gid~.asp ''Lactarius subdulcis''] at RogersMushrooms {{good article}} {{Taxonbar|from=Q1724711}} [[Category:Lactarius|subdulcis]] [[Category:Edible fungi]] [[Category:Fungi described in 1801]] [[Category:Fungi of Europe]] [[Category:Taxa named by Christiaan Hendrik Persoon]]
